div1.head: Biography of Walter Reed, by Christopher Reed, [1903?]
div1.p:
Sketch written by Walter Reed's brother - Christopher. (See p 6)
P S H

Walter Reed, M. D., M. A., L. L. D., was born on the 13th day of
September A. D. 1851, in Gloucester County, Virginia, and was the son
of Lemuel Sutton Reed, a native of North Carolina, who was for forty
years or more a leading Methodist Divine of Virginia,. His mother's
maiden name was Pharaba White, a native of North Carolina, a woman of
charming sweetness of character with a good and creditable ancestry.
Five children were the issue of this marriage, here named in the order
of their birth: Laura, James, Thomas, Christopher, and Walter, the
deceased. He was descended in a direct line on the male side from
Sir Christopher Reed of Chipchase Castle on the Tyne, England, and his
son Thomas, was in his day, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. In common with
the great statesman Thomas Brackett Reed, of Maine, his lineage, so
far as historical data can be relied upon, may be traced back to one
Bryanus de Rede, a prominent officer in the army of William, the Norman
Conqueror.

In personal appearance the subject of this sketch in his
childhood was highly favored, and to this he added the sweetest
disposition and most gracious manners. So pleasing was his person,
when a child, that our father pointing to him was accustomed to say to
our mother: “What a choice temple for the Almighty to dwell in.”
He was interesting from his early youth, and the family reluctantly
dined without his presence. My father was accustomed to say: “Wait
children till your youngest brother comes.” All of us desired the
joy of his conversation and the clear ring of his laughter, which,
to me, was as sweet as the “Chimes of Normandy” or “The Bells of
Shandon.” The tabernacle of the home was never complete until he
entered it with his cheery smile. He was of a happy nature. He
found “tongues in trees, books in running brooks, sermons in stones,
and good in everything.”

As a boy he was very precocious; he mastered with ease all
the little problems that come to youth. At thirteen years of age
2.
he was a good Greek and Latin scholar, and at fifteen years
of age he understood these studies with great accuracy. He
was an omnivorous reader in his youth. He was particularly
fond of history, literature and philosophy, and from them he
had memorized the choicest selections. His favorite poet was
Sir Walter Scott, and from this author he selected the finest
passages, and would recite them with great beauty. There was
no subject which his mind could not grasp and solve even when
a boy, and he did it all without pride. Never once after his
greatest success was there ever noticed in his face even the
semblance of the spirit of the self-congratulatory words:
“veni, vidi, vici,” which more or less always fills the breast
of a proud man who has accomplished his task. He was modest
at all times; and after all modesty is a safe and reliable
evidence of true greatness. Every modest man is not great,
but it is equally true that every great man is modest. As
“Nature abhors a vacuum,” so he detested a pretender; naught
but a genuine, golden merit could arrest his attention.

By a special dispensation, as I now recall, of the Faculty
of the University of Virginia, he was matriculated at the age
of sixteen as a student of that great University. He pursued
with great success a number of studies during his first year
and was always among those who obtained the highest mark in
his classes. As my father's means were limited and there
were two other sons at the University of Virginia at the same
time, the subject of this sketch realized that he would not be
able to complete the full course in the Academic departments.
He therefore, at the ensuing session, selected the study of
medicine and in one session of nine months graduated with the
honor and title of M. D. at the age of seventeen years.

This was an unusual feat, and the first of its character
since the immortal Jefferson laid the corner stone of this, one
of the greatest American institutions of learning. During
the time he was a pupil in the medical class, Doctor Cabell,
then a leading member of the medical faculty, told my father
that the task undertaken by my brother Walter to graduate at
his age in the short space of nine months was too much, and
that he, Walter, should be persuaded to abandon the same. My
brother replied to that by saying: “I do not fear the result.”
Ordinarily, students took a course of two or three years to
acquire the degree of M. D., but the subject of this sketch
attained that honor at the age of seventeen, and in one
session of nine months. He was one of nine out of a class
of nearly one-hundred, as I remember, that passed the examination
and secured the degree. He was an enthusiastic student.
I was his room-mate, and I recall very vividly that during this
time, in the year 1869, he was accustomed for three or four
months in succession to allow himself only three or four hours
sleep out of the twenty-four, and I recollect very distinctly
that on two or three occasions he studied uninterruptedly for
three days and nights without a moment's sleep, and did, as a
result of such an effort, suddenly collapse falling upon the
floor of his room into the deepest slumber.

In a few months after his graduation, which was in 1869,
he left for New York City, and there matriculated as a student
of Bellevue Hospital Medical College, and in one session acquired
the degree of M. D.. With his former preparation this degree
was so easily acquired that he was enabled to give three -
fourths of his time to the clinics of the hospitals and to other
intellectual persuits; for if Beecher or Chapin were to preach,
Tyndall, Huxley, or Froude to lecture, Booth or Neilson to act,
4.
O'Connor or Evarts to argue in court, he could always be found
in the audience.

div1.p:
After finishing his course at the Bellevue Hospital Medical
College he was attached to several of the hospitals of Brooklyn
and New York. He was located at the Hospital on Randall's
Island in the vicinity of New York, where he went to study the
diseases of children. He was for a time House Surgeon of
the Brooklyn City Hospital. As I now recollect he had four
or five diplomas of the hospitals of Brooklyn and New York,
certifying to the fact that he had passed through them and dis-
charged his duty faithfully. He was also before he was
twenty-one years of age District physician of one of the
districts of New York, where it became his duty to administer
to the poor; and this duty he discharged with the greatest
fidelity. At this time I was his room-mate, having gone to
New York to practice law. While acting in this capacity he
never failed to respond to every call, however lowly, even
though the same should take him into the most dangerous quarters
of the city at the most critical hours of the night. On one
occasion he returned to his room very late at night from one
of these professional calls. He entered the room and I made
no manifestation that I was awake. He walked to the window of
the room and there remained some time looking into the
street, for it was a bright night; after remaining there a while
I heard him speak slowly and with a deeply pathetic tone these
words: “Wo unto thee Chorazin, wo unto thee Bethsaida, for if
the mighty works which were done in you had been done in
Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in sackcloth
and ashes.” I concluded that he was reflecting upon the
wickedness of a great city. He afterwards undressed himself
5.
and kneeling down by the bedside repeated in distinct tones
that greatest symphony of the soul, the Lord's Prayer. The
whole occasion was so solemn and beautiful, that I never
alluded to it; for there are some things too sacred for the
invasion of words. I only speak of them now to illustrate the
character and trend of his thought while yet a young man.

While at a Brooklyn City Hospital he attracted the atten-
tion of one of its visiting surgeons and physicians, Dr.
Joseph Hutchinson, who was then regarded as the leading physi-
cian and surgeon of Brooklyn. Through the influence of this
acquaintance he subsequently acquired the position of one of
five Inspectors on the Board of Health of the City of Brooklyn,
and was holding this position when only twenty-two years of age.
He was regarded universally by those of his profession who
knew him while in New York as a young man of the highest talent,
and was especially known among his professional acquaintances
for his great skill in surgery. Several of them spoke to me
on this subject in most laudatory terms. In 1874, he stated
to me that there were too many able doctors doing too
little in the City of New York; that success in his line seemed
to be dependent very largely upon social connection and
wealthy, influential friends; that as he was unable to rely upon
this source for his success he had determined to go into the
army or navy where his future could be secured, and where at
the same time he could pursue his researches in medicine. Early
in 1875, in compliance with this intention, after a most brilliant
examination, he entered the army where his record is known to
all his professional brethren. As a boy he possessed the
same power he displayed as a man. He had great courage,
and under no circumstances would be relinquish the task which
6.
he had undertaken. When twelve years of age, when the ther-
mometer was ten degrees below zero on an occasion of great
urgency, accompanied by a man servant, he took a long journey
of two or three days over difficult roads into the country.
This journey was made on behalf of my father and he accomplished
the work for which he had been sent with great success, and I
can now see him as he returned; with joy he sprang out of the
conveyance which brought him safely back and ran into my father's
arms and said: “Pa, everything is all right, I have got the money
here in my pocket.” This only illustrates the character of
the man. It was literally true of him that the “boy was
father to the man.” When a young man he was as dignified
as Chesterfield and as gracious as a great heart could make
him, the knightliest of the knightly, a Cavalier among his
fellows. He had a great contempt for ostentation and display.
He never “blew his own trumpet.” With the faith of a strong
man he was content to await the rewards which always come from
results justly and worthily obtained. He saw the thing to be
done and however difficult he did it. His master spirit knew
no defeat and his great soul knew no pride. His whole life,
however successful, was in harmony with that great line of the
poet:- “Oh, why should the spirit of mortal be proud?” The
writer of this sketch, his brother Christopher, received a
letter from him some three or four months ago in which he spoke
of the interesting work which he had already mapped out to ac-
complish. He expressed himself with great satisfaction at the
result of his labors in Cuba, in finding the cause and remedy for
that most devastating epidemic, yellow fever. He acknowledged
in his letter that in conducting the experiments which he conducted
in Cuba that he went down into the “valley and shadow of death,”
but he thanked God that he had been enabled to do so with
7.
the expectation of accomplishing great results for afflicted
humanity. And in the same letter he expressed the desire to
live until he might set upon foot other investigations that
would result in the destruction of many of the epidemics that
now prevail, distress and afflict humanity.

He appreciated highly the honor of L.L. D. conferred on
him by Ann Arbor University and M. A. by Harvard University.
But in a letter to me he said to me that while these honors were
pleasing to him, that the chief source of his joy was that he had
been able to do something for afflicted humanity, and that his
life had not been spent in vain.

He was devoted to his family and always spoke of them
with the greatest affection, and undoubtedly was giving his
best efforts to make them happy. He was very fond of his
son, a lieutenant in the Philippines, and always made reference
to him in letters written to myself. I am not familiar with
his home life, as we have been living apart since 1875, in
extreme sections of the country, but I undertake to say that
he entertained the highest ideal of home and that he discharged
the relation of husband and father judged by the very strictest
and highest standard.

He possessed other powers beside those displayed in his
profession. He was a profound thinker on all subjects and
cultivated the whole range of thought. At a medical banquet
in New York at the age of twenty-two years I heard him make
an address which, for sublime and chaste eloquence and a
high conception of the relationship of man to man, I have
never heard surpassed. If he had taken up the study of law
he would have been known as a great lawyer with extraordinary
powers of oratory. If he had gone into the ministry, he
would have charmed and enchanted his audience by the strength
8.
and character of his thought and the purity of his style.
As it was he selected the field of medicine, and the glory of
his record in that line is attested by all of his professional breth-
ren. He was intensely spiritual by nature; all of his work
was subordinated to that conception of things. He worked wholly
in the light of Divine impulses and was in touch with its finest
inspiration and worshipped daily at its unseen altars.
He was God's child, especially endowed to work in God's vine-
yard for God. He was a messenger commissioned to deliver the
Divine message, and he delivered it. There is the man and
there is his work, and if you would know more of him, I point
for an answer to those memorable words engravened upon the
memorial tablet of Sir Christopher Wren in the Cathedral of
St. Paul in London: “Si monumentum quaeris, circumspice.”
Of him might be justly said as Livy the historian said of Cato
the Greater: “In illo viro tantum robur corporis et animi fuit
ut quocunque loco natus esset, fortunam sibi facturus videretur.”

But first and foremost, he was in truth, a good man, right-
eous in every thought. He breathed the oxygen of moral alti-
tudes; sooner than adandon the cause of truth, he would have,
refused like Moses of old, to have been called the son of
Pharaoh's daughter. He was as faithful to his convictions
as historic John Maynard, the brave pilot on burning ship, was
faithful to the commands of his captain; when and wherever duty
called his great soul made response with the “Aye, aye Sir”
of midnight watch on tempest tossed sea. With him there was
no greatness without goodness. It was not the great Napoleon
at Austerlitz, but the great and good Washington at Valley Forge
that elicited his admiration and praise.

He believed that the philosophy of the Nazarene alone
could unravel the mystery of human life and give to it a meaning.

The Sermon on the Mount was his religious chart, “A cloud
by day and a pillar of fire by night” to point the way, which
he always found, and in which he walked unerringly. He made
love not to the continuance of his days, but to their goodness.
The Maccabees in their zeal inscribed upon their banners these
words: “Moriamur in nostra simplicitate.” He inscribed upon
his banner these better words: “The world is my parish and to
do good is my religion;” in his heart, therefore, naturally and
continually dwelt the sentiment, which little Paul dying, in
“Dombey and Son,” whispered to his sister Florence, as he saw
the beautiful visions of the life to come: “Tell them that
the face of the picture of Christ on the staircase at school
is not divine enough; and the light from it is shining on me now.”

Our brother died comparatively young, just as he was
ascending the summit of his life's work to catch the light of
things more divine. But it has been well said: “After all be a
course short or long, it is complete in the eyes of the Great
Master to whom we reverently commit all our ways. There is no
broken column. The Supreme Architect finishes the shaft.”

Here we leave our beloved; and as Margarita said to
Faust on the eve of their final separation, so now we say to
our precious departed: “Think of me sometime, for I shall think
of you all the time.” We do not say good bye, but only, “Aufwie-
dersehn,” for we shall meet again.
